ygData.subject: Re: [neat] unassigned input values for Neural Net
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Jeff, I suppose it depends on what sort of input signals we re dealing with. E.g. say it s cart velocity in the pole balancing problem and to increase

From: "Colin Green" <colin.green1@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] unassigned input values for Neural Net
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770313; y=cJthBMolw7l7inSkTuRYmTS9kO2I-wzbASFTrP82g9YFg72jNoL3
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Jeff,

I suppose it depends on what sort of input signals we're dealing with.
E.g. say it's cart velocity in the pole balancing problem and to
increase difficulty we make the velocity input intermittent - so
there's a dodgy connection somewhere.

So now the ANN doesn't know if a zero means the cart is stationary or
if the connection is broken. In this particular case the ANN can learn
that a cart has momentum, such that if velocity sharply drops to zero
then we can probably assume the input is wrong and estimate the true
velocity from past inputs (using recurrent connections) . However the
problem is easier if we have another input telling us the connection
is broken - we don't have to evolve structure to do work that out and
the ANN can flip immediately to it's velocity estimate sub-net.

So my instinct on this one (in the genral case) is that if we overload
an input then NEAT will typically have to evolve some structure to try
and distinguish between the distinct overload cases - which generally
will be more difficult than if you just tell the ANN directly that the
input is currently dead.

An additional 100 inputs sounds bad, but it's not as bad as trying to
evolve 100 substructures trying to do something potentially complex.

Colin.
